prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: The world-famous 'great detective', above whose lodgings Miss Susato and I rent our own office and rooms.
Character 2
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 3
Name: Pop Windibank
Description: The proprietor of a pawnbrokery on Baker Street that is regularly patronised by Mr Sholmes. He has a very great sense of responsibility to his clients.
Character 4
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A young pickpocket who we first met during a trial two months ago. She and Iris have become firm friends since.
Character 5
Name: Eggert Benedict → Ashley Graydon
Description: A young English gentleman with an aloof and high-handed manner. He appeared at Windibank's pawnbrokery accusing Gina of stealing his redemption ticket.
Character 6
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 7
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: The infamous London-based prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Further details about the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Nash Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Ringo. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Character 10
Name: Ringo Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Nash. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Music Box Disk
Description: A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. The piece of music, which remains unidentified, is stored on the disk by means of small protrusions. A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. On the reverse side is a note that reads, 'For McGilded'.
Evidence 2
Name: White Cat Photograph → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Box)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat, obtained from Gina while interviewing her in her prison cell. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank, in the form of some hand-written notes on the back of a photograph.
Evidence 3
Name: Gina's Representation Papers
Description: The paperwork signed by Gina to put me in charge of her defence. Showing this to Scotland Yard detectives gains us access to the crime scene.
Evidence 4
Name: White Cat Photograph #2 → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Coat)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat. I feel as though I have another print just like this one... A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. There's what looks like a bloody fingermark on it. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. The blood on it has been identified as Mr Mason's.
Evidence 5
Name: Blood Samples Portfolio
Description: A sample of blood analysed with a special chemical indicator developed by Mr Sholmes. Different people's blood turns different colours.
Evidence 6
Name: Iris's Story Manuscript
Description: A long, unpublished story that Mr Sholmes deposited at the pawnbrokery of the victim, Mr Windibank. It's entitled 'The Hound of the Baskervilles'.
Evidence 7
Name: McGilded Case Notes
Description: Notes collated by Miss Susato about the McGilded case that we worked on two months ago.
Evidence 8
Name: Today's Paper
Description: This morning's paper, purchased by Iris. Gina's case features prominently. This morning's paper, which contains an article about government secrets being leaked to foreign agencies.
Evidence 9
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma.
Evidence 10
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.
Evidence 11
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of Windibank's pawnbrokery, the scene of the crime. It shows the relative positions of the main shop and the rear storeroom.
Evidence 12
Name: Windibank's Gun
Description: A gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge.
Evidence 13
Name: Skulkin Brothers' Gun
Description: A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired.
Evidence 14
Name: Photograph of Gina
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene a short time before the murder took place.
Evidence 15
Name: Post-Shooting Photograph
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene after the murder had taken place.
Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18
Name: The Third Bullet
Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.
Evidence 20
Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Alright, we did knock a few things over. But we weren't riflin' fer nuffin'!
Person: Nash
Testimony 1
Testimony: It woz when we 'eard the gunshot, see. Made us both jump, an' all that stuff went flyin'.
Person: Ringo
Testimony 2
Testimony: Just before the gunshot, we 'eard a voice yellin' out, 'Gimme that gun!'
Person: Ringo
Testimony 3
Testimony: The bloke wot owned the place was 'oldin' a gun, so 'e should 'ave just fired instead of yellin' at the girl!
Person: Nash
Testimony 4
Testimony: Lummy, it didn't 'alf gimme a fright! We woz thinkin' the shooter'd come out the door and get us next.
Person: Nash
Testimony 5
Testimony: We stuck everyfin' back where we found it and scarpered...straight into 'im in the black.
Person: Ringo
Testimony 6
Testimony: We couldn't 'ave shot the pawnbroker, see! We never even 'ad a chance, did we?
Person: Nash

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let's start by going through each testimony and see which evidence might conflict with it.

First, the characters involved are the Skulkin brothers (Nash and Ringo), who are witnesses and alleged accomplices in the pawnbrokery break-in. The testimonies provided are from both Nash and Ringo.

Looking at Testimony 0 by Nash: "Alright, we did knock a few things over. But we weren't riflin' fer nuffin'!" So he's saying they didn't steal anything, just knocked things over. 

Testimony 1 by Ringo: "It woz when we 'eard the gunshot, see. Made us both jump, an' all that stuff went flyin'." Here, Ringo claims they heard the gunshot first, which caused them to jump and things to fly. That implies the gunshot happened before they were there, or during their break-in, but they didn't cause the shooting.

Testimony 2 by Ringo: "Just before the gunshot, we 'eard a voice yellin' out, 'Gimme that gun!'" This suggests that before the gunshot, someone was demanding a gun. So the sequence here is: someone yells, then gunshot. 

Testimony 3 by Nash: "The bloke wot owned the place was 'oldin' a gun, so 'e should 'ave just fired instead of yellin' at the girl!" Nash is saying the pawnbroker had a gun and should have shot instead of yelling at Gina. 

Testimony 4 by Nash: "Lummy, it didn't 'alf gimme a fright! We woz thinkin' the shooter'd come out the door and get us next." So they were scared the shooter would come after them, implying they weren't the shooters. 

Testimony 5 by Ringo: "We stuck everyfin' back where we found it and scarpered...straight into 'im in the black." They put things back and ran into someone in black. 

Testimony 6 by Nash: "We couldn't 'ave shot the pawnbroker, see! We never even 'ad a chance, did we?" They claim they didn't shoot the pawnbroker.

Now, looking at the evidences. Let's see which ones might conflict with these testimonies.

Evidence 12: Windibank's Gun - "a gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge."

Evidence 13: Skulkin Brothers' Gun - "a firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired."

Evidence 9: Autopsy Report - "confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back."

Evidence 10: Crime Scene Photograph - shows the victim with a single bullet wound.

Evidence 18: The Third Bullet - "a projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes." So there's a third bullet involved here.

Wait, the Autopsy Report says a single bullet caused death, but the Third Bullet evidence suggests another bullet hit Sholmes. So maybe two bullets were fired? That might be a contradiction, but that's between evidence and other evidence, not a testimony.

Looking back at the testimonies, Nash and Ringo say they didn't shoot, and that the pawnbroker was holding a gun. The evidence about the Skulkin's gun having a fired round would suggest they did fire a shot. But the autopsy says only one bullet killed the pawnbroker. If the Skulkin's gun was fired, maybe that's the shot that killed him, but they claim they weren't the shooters. 

Testimony 6 says they couldn't have shot the pawnbroker. But if their gun was fired, that would contradict their testimony. So Evidence 13 (Skulkin's gun had a fired round) vs Testimony 6 (they couldn't have shot him). That's a contradiction.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says the pawnbroker was holding a gun and should have shot instead of yelling. If the pawnbroker's gun was discharged (Evidence 12 says it was discharged), then maybe the pawnbroker fired, but the autopsy says the bullet came from the back. If the pawnbroker was shot from behind, he couldn't have shot himself. So if the pawnbroker's gun was fired, maybe someone else used it. But the evidence says Gina was holding it when found unconscious, but the discharge could be from when she was shot? Not sure.

Alternatively, the Skulkin brothers' gun (Evidence 13) having a fired round would mean they fired a shot. If that's the bullet that killed Windibank, then their testimony (Testimony 6) that they didn't shoot him would be contradicted by Evidence 13. 

Yes, that seems like a contradiction. Evidence 13 (their gun fired) vs Testimony 6 (they couldn't have shot him). So the answer would be {"evidence":13, "testimony":6}.
</think>

Person: Graydon

cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each evidence and testimony carefully.

First, looking at the characters and the case: the victim is Pop Windibank, the pawnbroker. The defendant is Eggert Benedict → Ashley Graydon, accused of some involvement in the murder. The testimonies provided are all from Graydon, denying any involvement and dismissing the evidence against him. 

Now, let's look at the evidences. Evidence 4 mentions a pawnbroker's ticket with blood identified as Mr. Mason's. Wait, but the victim here is Windibank, so maybe that's from a previous case? Hmm, but the main case here is Windibank's murder. Let me check again. Evidence 4's description says the blood is identified as Mr. Mason's. But in this case, the victim is Windibank. Maybe that's a different case, like the SS-5 incident from before?

Looking at Evidence 5: Blood Samples Portfolio. It says different people's blood turn different colors when analyzed with Sholmes's indicator. So if there's blood evidence linked to Graydon at the scene, that would contradict his testimony denying involvement.

Graydon's Testimony 3 says he doesn't admit to the accusation even if his blood was found. But Evidence 5 could be the portfolio showing his blood was there, contradicting his denial. Wait, but the Blood Samples Portfolio (Evidence 5) is general, not specifically stating that his blood was found. 

Wait, Evidence 4 has a ticket with blood identified as Mason's. Maybe Mason is another person. The key here is Testimony 3 where Graydon says even if his blood was found, he denies it. But which evidence actually shows his blood?

Looking at Evidence 5's description: it's a portfolio of blood samples analyzed. If there's a sample from the crime scene that matches Graydon's blood, then that would contradict his testimony. But the problem is, the specific evidence that shows his blood is present might not be explicitly stated here. Let me check all evidences again.

Evidence 4's description says the blood on the ticket is Mason's. Evidence 5 is the portfolio that can analyze blood. Maybe the blood at the scene (like on Windibank's body or elsewhere) was analyzed, and if it's Graydon's, then that would contradict his testimony. But the given evidences don't explicitly state that. Wait, perhaps Evidence 5 is used to analyze a blood sample from the scene (like from Evidence 12 or 13), and if that's Graydon's blood, then that's the contradiction.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 by Graydon dismisses the blood evidence as "homebrewed tincture", but Evidence 5's method is the one he's referring to. If the Blood Samples Portfolio (Evidence 5) is proven reliable, then his dismissal is invalid. But the question is about direct contradiction between an evidence and testimony.

Wait, Testimony 3 says "Even if certain parties here present claim that my blood was found at the scene." So he's acknowledging that there's a claim his blood was found. The contradiction would be if an evidence actually confirms that his blood was found. But which evidence does that?

Looking at Evidence 4: it's a pawn ticket with blood identified as Mason's. Not Graydon's. Evidence 5 is the method, but not the result. Maybe another evidence? Let me check all again.

Evidence 19 is a music box disk with a note for McGilded. Not related to blood. Evidence 12 is Windibank's gun with a single discharge. Evidence 13 is the brothers' gun. Evidence 9 is the autopsy report showing a bullet wound. 

Wait, perhaps the blood on the ticket in Evidence 4 is actually Graydon's, but the description says it's Mason's. Maybe that's a mistake? Or maybe Evidence 5's portfolio was used to test the blood and found it's Graydon's, contradicting Testimony 3.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 3 is denying that his blood was found, but Evidence 5's analysis shows it was. Since Evidence 5 is the portfolio that can do that analysis, maybe the combination of Evidence 5 and some other evidence (like a blood sample from the scene) would show his blood. But since the problem requires just one evidence and testimony pair, perhaps the key is that Testimony 4 dismisses the blood evidence method (Evidence 5's technique), but Evidence 5's validity would contradict that. 

Alternatively, if there's an evidence that explicitly states Graydon's blood was found, then that would contradict his testimony. Since I don't see that explicitly, maybe I'm missing something. Let me check the testimonies again.

Graydon's Testimony 5 says he's never been to the pawnbrokery. But if there's evidence of his presence, like his blood being there, that would contradict. 

Wait, Evidence 4's description says the blood on the ticket is Mason's. Maybe Mason is a different person involved. If there's another blood sample from the scene linked to Graydon, but perhaps it's in Evidence 5's portfolio. Since the portfolio can analyze different blood, maybe there's an analysis result showing his blood, but it's not listed as a separate evidence. 

Hmm, perhaps I need to consider that the Blood Samples Portfolio (Evidence 5) is the method used to determine that his blood was present, which he denies. So the existence of Evidence 5's method, combined with the fact that his blood was found (even if not explicitly stated), might be the contradiction. But the question requires a direct contradiction between an evidence and testimony pair. 

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 says the blood evidence is unreliable, but Evidence 5's portfolio is the reliable method, so that's a contradiction. But the testimony is about the blood being his, not the method's validity. 

Wait, Testimony 4: "The bottom line is, I've never had anything to do with the pawnbroking establishment where the man was killed!" If there's an evidence showing he was there, like his blood, that's the contradiction. Since the blood on the ticket in Evidence 4 is Mason's, not his, maybe another evidence? 

Looking again, Evidence 14 is a photo of Gina taken by the Red-Handed Recorder before the murder. Evidence 15 is after. Maybe those photos show Graydon there. But the testimonies don't mention that. 

Alternatively, maybe the Music Box Disk (Evidence 1) has a note for McGilded, which could link to Graydon's involvement via previous case notes (Evidence 7). But that's more circumstantial. 

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 3 ("Even if certain parties claim my blood was found...") and Evidence 5 (which is the method to analyze blood, implying that his blood was indeed found). Since the testimony dismisses the blood evidence, but the evidence's method is valid, that's a contradiction. 

Alternatively, maybe there's an evidence that directly states his blood was found. Since I can't see it, maybe I'm missing it. Let me check Evidence 4 again. It says the blood on the ticket is Mason's. Evidence 5 is the portfolio. Maybe the blood at the crime scene (like on Windibank's body) was analyzed via Evidence 5 and found to be Graydon's. But since that's not explicitly stated in the evidence descriptions, maybe the problem expects this pairing. 

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 3's statement that his blood wasn't there contradicts Evidence 5's ability to detect it. But the testimony is about the presence, not the method. 

Hmm, perhaps I need to think differently. Let me look for another angle. 

Looking at Testimony 0: Graydon says he uses pawnbroking services. Testimony 5 says he's never been there. That's a contradiction in his own testimonies? No, because Testimony 0 could be about other pawnbrokers, not Windibank's. 

Wait, Testimony 5: "I've never had anything to do with the pawnbroking establishment where the man was killed!" So he denies being at Windibank's. If there's evidence he was there, like his blood or something else, that's the contradiction. 

Evidence 5's portfolio could have analyzed blood samples from the scene and found his blood. Since the portfolio is the method, maybe the actual analysis result is part of the portfolio, making Evidence 5 and Testimony 3 contradictory. 

Alternatively, maybe Evidence 4's blood being Mason's is irrelevant, but another evidence like the pawn ticket (Evidence 2 or 4) has his blood. Wait, Evidence 4's description says the blood is Mason's, so not him. 

Hmm, perhaps I'm overcomplicating. Let me see the options again. The user wants one pair. 

Another angle: Testimony 4 says the blood evidence is unreliable (homebrewed tincture), but Evidence 5's method is the portfolio, implying it's reliable. So Testimony 4's dismissal contradicts Evidence 5's validity. 

Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 5 and Testimony 4. 

So the answer would be {"evidence":5, "testimony":4}.
</think>

Evidence 9
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma.
Evidence 10
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.
Evidence 11
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan

Evidence 12
Name: Windibank's Gun
Description: A gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge.
Evidence 13
Name: Skulkin Brothers' Gun
Description: A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired.
Evidence 14
Name: Photograph of Gina
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene a short time before the murder took place.
Evidence 15
Name: Post-Shooting Photograph
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene after the murder had taken place.
Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18
Name: The Third Bullet
Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.
Evidence 20
Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: There's a note on the disk saying, 'For McGilded', but the item belongs to me.
Person: Graydon

Testimony 3

Person: Graydon
Testimony 4
Testimony: In other words...I had absolutely no reason to break into the shop later that same night.
Person: Graydon

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: The world-famous 'great detective', above whose lodgings Miss Susato and I rent our own office and rooms.
Character 2
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 3
Name: Pop Windibank
Description: The proprietor of a pawnbrokery on Baker Street that is regularly patronised by Mr Sholmes. He has a very great sense of responsibility to his clients.
Character 4
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A young pickpocket who we first met during a trial two months ago. She and Iris have become firm friends since.
Character 5
Name: Eggert Benedict → Ashley Graydon
Description: A young English gentleman with an aloof and high-handed manner. He appeared at Windibank's pawnbrokery accusing Gina of stealing his redemption ticket.
Character 6
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 7
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: The infamous London-based prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Further details about the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Nash Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Ringo. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Character 10
Name: Ringo Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Nash. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Music Box Disk
Description: A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. The piece of music, which remains unidentified, is stored on the disk by means of small protrusions. A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. On the reverse side is a note that reads, 'For McGilded'.
Evidence 2
Name: White Cat Photograph → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Box)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat, obtained from Gina while interviewing her in her prison cell. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank, in the form of some hand-written notes on the back of a photograph.
Evidence 3
Name: Gina's Representation Papers
Description: The paperwork signed by Gina to put me in charge of her defence. Showing this to Scotland Yard detectives gains us access to the crime scene.
Evidence 4
Name: White Cat Photograph #2 → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Coat)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat. I feel as though I have another print just like this one... A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. There's what looks like a bloody fingermark on it. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. The blood on it has been identified as Mr Mason's.
Evidence 5
Name: Blood Samples Portfolio
Description: A sample of blood analysed with a special chemical indicator developed by Mr Sholmes. Different people's blood turns different colours.
Evidence 6
Name: Iris's Story Manuscript
Description: A long, unpublished story that Mr Sholmes deposited at the pawnbrokery of the victim, Mr Windibank. It's entitled 'The Hound of the Baskervilles'.
Evidence 7
Name: McGilded Case Notes
Description: Notes collated by Miss Susato about the McGilded case that we worked on two months ago.
Evidence 8
Name: Today's Paper
Description: This morning's paper, purchased by Iris. Gina's case features prominently. This morning's paper, which contains an article about government secrets being leaked to foreign agencies.
Evidence 9
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma.
Evidence 10
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.

Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene a short time before the murder took place.

Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene after the murder had taken place.
Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18
Name: The Third Bullet
Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.
Evidence 20
Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: A mere communications officer couldn't possibly steal confidential government information!
Person: Graydon
Testimony 1
Testimony: Besides, the sounds produced by that music box aren't even Morse code!
Person: Graydon
Testimony 2
Testimony: It was some low-class brickmaker negotiating with McGilded anyway, was it not? I've no relation to the man!
Person: Graydon
Testimony 3
Testimony: Look, all we dun is break into the gaff the other night like wot 'e told us to do!
Person: Nash
Testimony 4
Testimony: If we'd known there woz dodgy gov'ment secrets involved, we wouldn't 'ave touched it!
Person: Ringo
Testimony 5
Testimony: 'Milverton & Skulkin's Milk Run'... Gor, them were the days!
Person: Nash

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:

But Testimony 1 by Graydon is specifically denying that the music box uses Morse code. 

Wait, but the contradiction might be elsewhere. Let me check other evidences. Evidence 1 is the Music Box Disk which has a note saying "For McGilded." The description also mentions that the music is stored via small protrusions. Morse code uses dots and dashes, which could be represented by such protrusions. If the music box's disk uses protrusions that could encode Morse code, then Graydon's testimony that it's not Morse code would contradict that. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is with another evidence. Let me look again. 

Testimony 2 by Graydon also mentions a brickmaker negotiating with McGilded. Evidence 7 is the McGilded Case Notes, which are about the previous case involving McGilded. But maybe the evidence's description implies it's used for encoding in another way, conflicting with Graydon's statement?

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 1 (Graydon says music box isn't Morse code) and Evidence 1's description which might imply it is. Let me recheck Evidence 1's full description: "A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. The piece of music, which remains unidentified, is stored on the disk by means of small protrusions. A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. On the reverse side is a note that reads, 'For McGilded'." The protrusions might be arranged in a way that could represent Morse code, even if the music itself isn't recognized. Graydon's testimony denies it's Morse, but the evidence might suggest otherwise through the protrusions' pattern. 

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 0 from Graydon says the music box belongs to him and the note is for McGilded. If the music box is part of a scheme to send coded messages (Morse), then his testimony that it's not Morse would contradict the evidence's implication. 

Alternatively, Evidence 19's music box might be linked. The small music box with a single tone could be a red herring, but if the disk (Evidence 1) is the one used for Morse, then the contradiction is there. 

Hmm. Alternatively, looking at Testimony 2 by Graydon mentions a brickmaker negotiating with McGilded. If Evidence 7 (McGilded Case Notes) includes information about the brickmaker, then Graydon's denial of relation would contradict that. But the description of Evidence 7 just says it's notes about the McGilded case from two months ago. Unless the brickmaker was part of that case, which isn't stated here, so maybe not. 

Another possibility: Testimony 4 by Ringo says they wouldn't have touched it if they knew about government secrets. Evidence 8's newspaper mentions the leak, so if the music box was part of that, then the brothers' testimony about not knowing might conflict with evidence showing they were involved. But that's more about their knowledge, which might not be directly contradictory unless evidence proves they did know. 

Wait, perhaps Testimony 1 (Graydon says music box isn't Morse) vs Evidence 1's disk's protrusions could be the key. If the protrusions are arranged in Morse code, then the testimony contradicts the evidence. But the evidence doesn't explicitly say that. However, the note says "For McGilded," which might imply a coded message. The testimony denies Morse, but the evidence's description's protrusions could be Morse. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 1 and Evidence 1's note. The note mentions McGilded, so if the music box's purpose was to send a message to McGilded via Morse, then Graydon's denial would conflict. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 0 by Graydon says the disk belongs to him, but Evidence 1's description says it's for McGilded. So if the disk is Graydon's but the note is for McGilded, maybe that's a contradiction? Wait, the testimony says the note is on the disk, but Graydon claims it belongs to him. So maybe he's lying about ownership if the note is addressed to someone else. But that's a different angle. 

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 2 by Graydon says he has no relation to the brickmaker (Mason?), but Evidence 4's pawn ticket has blood identified as Mason's. If Graydon was involved with Mason, that would conflict. But the testimony is about the brickmaker negotiating with McGilded, not directly with Graydon. 

Hmm, this is tricky. Let me go back. 

The user wants one pair. The most plausible is Testimony 1 (Graydon says music box isn't Morse code) and Evidence 1's description where the disk's protrusions might be encoding Morse. The testimony directly contradicts the possibility that the music box was used for Morse code, but the evidence's structure (protrusions) might imply that. 

Alternatively, the contradiction is between Testimony 1 and Evidence 1's note: the note says "For McGilded," suggesting it's intended for him, but Graydon claims it belongs to him. Maybe he's the one it's for, but he denies any relation. Not sure. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 2: "the brickmaker negotiating with McGilded anyway, I've no relation to the man!" If Evidence 7's McGilded Case Notes mention Graydon's involvement with the brickmaker (Mason?), then that's a contradiction. But the description of Evidence 7 doesn't say that, so maybe not. 

Wait, Evidence 4's pawn ticket has blood identified as Mason's. If Graydon was involved with Mason, that's conflicting. But the testimony is about no relation to the brickmaker (Mason?), so if the blood is Mason's, maybe Mason's involvement ties Graydon, but testimony denies that. 

Alternatively, Testimony 0 says Graydon's disk was taken by police, but Evidence 1 is the disk with McGilded's note. So if the disk was taken, but the note is there, maybe he's lying about ownership. 

Hmm. Alternatively, Testimony 1's denial that the music box uses Morse code might conflict with Evidence 19's music box which might be part of a system to send coded messages. Since Evidence 19's description says it plays a single tone, maybe that's a Morse code signal (dots and dashes via timing), even with same tone. So Graydon's testimony that it's not Morse would be contradicted by the fact that it can send Morse via timing. 

In that case, the contradiction is between Evidence 1 (or 19?) and Testimony 1. Let me check the evidence numbers again:

Evidence 19: Small Music Box that plays a single tone.

The testimony is about the music box's sounds not being Morse. Another possibility: Testimony 0 by Graydon claims the disk belongs to him, but the note on it says "For McGilded", implying it's for someone else. Thus, Testimony 0 contradicts the evidence's note. So Evidence 1's note vs Testimony 0. 

That could be a contradiction. If the disk is addressed to McGilded, then Graydon's claim that it belongs to him might be false.

Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.
Evidence 11
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of Windibank's pawnbrokery, the scene of the crime. It shows the relative positions of the main shop and the rear storeroom.
Evidence 12
Name: Windibank's Gun
Description: A gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge.
Evidence 13
Name: Skulkin Brothers' Gun
Description: A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired.
Evidence 14

Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene a short time before the murder took place.
Evidence 15

Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene after the murder had taken place.
Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18
Name: The Third Bullet
Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.
Evidence 20
Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimony 0

Person: Graydon
Testimony 1

Testimony 2

Person: Graydon

Person: Graydon
Testimony 4

Person: Graydon
Testimony 5

Person: Graydon

Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each evidence and testimony carefully.

First, let's look at the testimonies provided by Ashley Graydon (Character 5):

Testimony 3: Graydon accuses Gina (the accused in a black coat) of shooting Windibank in the back as he fled.
Testimony 4: He saw blood spatter on Gina.
Testimony 5: Gina tossed the gun out the peephole, which he picked up and escaped with.

Now, let's review the evidences. The key ones related to the testimonies might be:

Evidence 15 (Post-Shooting) might show Gina's position and whether she was holding the gun.

Looking at Testimony 5, Graydon says Gina tossed the gun out the peephole, and he picked it up. But Evidence 12 states that Gina was holding Windibank's gun when found unconscious. If she was holding it, that contradicts Graydon's claim that she tossed it out and he took it. 

Wait, but Testimony 3 says Gina shot Windibank. If she was holding the gun (Evidence 12), that might support her being the shooter. However, Graydon's Testimony 5 says he picked up the gun after she tossed it. If the evidence shows she was holding it, then the testimony that he picked it up after she tossed it would be conflicting. Because if she was holding it, she didn't toss it; instead, she might have been found with it. 

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says Gina shot Windibank in the back. The Autopsy Report (Evidence 9) confirms a single bullet wound from the back, which aligns with that. But the contradiction might be elsewhere.

Another angle: Testimony 2 says Graydon could see Windibank through the storeroom peephole. The Crime Scene Floor Plan (Evidence 11) shows the storeroom's position. If the plan shows the peephole's location, maybe there's a contradiction, but that's less likely.

Looking at Testimony 5 again: Graydon claims he picked up the gun after Gina tossed it out the peephole. But Evidence 12 says Gina was holding Windibank's gun when found unconscious. If she was holding it, she didn't toss it out; thus, Graydon's testimony about picking it up after she tossed it would be false. This seems like a contradiction between Evidence 12 and Testimony 5.

Wait, but Testimony 5 says he picked up the gun after she tossed it out the peephole. If the gun was found with Gina (Evidence 12), then Graydon's story that he took it after she threw it would be wrong. The evidence shows she had it, so the testimony that he took it contradicts that.

Alternatively, maybe the Skulkin brothers' gun (Evidence 13) is involved, but the description says Windibank's gun was the one Gina had.

Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 12 (Gina holding Windibank's gun) and Testimony 5 (Graydon says he picked up the gun after Gina tossed it). If she was holding it, she didn't toss it, so Testimony 5 is false.

So the pair would be Evidence 12 and Testimony 5. But the user wants only one pair. Let me check other possibilities.

Another point: Testimony 3 says Gina shot Windibank. The Autopsy (Evidence 9) says death was from a single bullet from the back. That aligns, so no contradiction there. 

Testimony 4 mentions blood spatter on Gina. Evidence 4's description has a bloody fingerprint on a ticket identified as Mason's blood. Not sure if that's related.

Alternatively, Testimony 0 says Graydon was near the entrance. If Evidence 14 (Photo of Gina before murder) or 15 (after) shows his position, but without the photo details, it's harder.

Another possible contradiction: Testimony 2 says Graydon saw Windibank through the storeroom's peephole. If the Floor Plan (Evidence 11) shows the storeroom's door doesn't have a peephole, that would conflict. But the Evidence 11's description says the plan shows main shop and storeroom positions, but doesn't mention peepholes. So maybe not.

The strongest contradiction is Evidence 12 vs Testimony 5. Let me confirm:

Evidence 12: Gina was holding Windibank's gun when found unconscious. Signs of single discharge.

Testimony 5: Graydon says Gina tossed the gun out the peephole, and he picked it up. If she was holding it, she couldn't have tossed it unless she picked it up again, which is unlikely. Hence, Testimony 5's account contradicts the evidence that she was holding the gun. Therefore, the answer should be Evidence 12 and Testimony 5.
